<ce:simple-para id="sp0040" view="all">(a) View of a portion of the 3D net in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> topology, bib ligands have two different conformations, <ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic> (red) and <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> (green). (b) Schematic representation of the 3D mode of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) View of a portion of the 3D net in 1 with CdSO4 topology, bib ligands have two different conformations, gauche-anti-gauche (red) and anti-anti-anti (green). (b) Schematic representation of the 3D mode of 1. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

Polymer 1 is a 3D CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> network while, 2 is a mononuclear complex. elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two Fe(II) coordination compounds with the flexible ligands 1,4-bis(imidazolyl)butane and 1,3-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl)propane were obtained with different structures. Polymer 1 is a 3D CdSO4 network while, 2 is a mononuclear complex. An attempted synthesis of [Fe(bbd)2(NCS)2] (bbd=1,4-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl)butane) was failed.

elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ The flexible ligands play a significant role in the formation and structures of iron(II) to coordination compounds.   ⋅ The bpp ligand adopts its common chelating mode of a single metal center in a mononuclear complex.   ⋅ The complexes have been characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental and thermal analyses and infrared spectroscopy.

elements.clean_text:
The flexible ligands play a significant role in the formation and structures of iron(II) to coordination compounds.

The bpp ligand adopts its common chelating mode of a single metal center in a mononuclear complex.

The complexes have been characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental and thermal analyses and infrared spectroscopy.

Abstract

Iron(II) coordination compounds [Fe(bib)2(NCS)2] n  (1) and [Fe(bpp)(NCS)2] (2) were synthesized by using the neutral flexible bidentate N-donor ligands 1,4-bis(imidazolyl)butane (bib) and 1,3-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl)propane (bpp), mono-anionic NCS- ligand and appropriate iron(II) salts. In the CdSO4 network structure of 1, the iron(II) ion lies on an inversion center and exhibits an FeN6 octahedral arrangement while, in the monomeric structure of 2, the iron(II) ion adopts an FeN4 tetrahedral geometry. In the complex 1, each μ2-bib acts as bridging ligand connecting two adjacent iron(II) ions while in the complex 2, the bpp ligand is coordinated to an iron(II) ion in a cyclic-bidentate fashion forming an eight-membered metallocyclic ring. Coordination compounds 1 and 2 have been characterized by infrared spectroscopy, elemental analyses and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Thermal analysis of polymer 1 was also studied. An attempt to synthesize [Fe(bbd)(NCS)2] (3) (bbd=1,4-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl)butane) with the reaction of bbd, Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2⋅6H2O and KNCS was failed.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The rational design and construction of iron coordination polymers have been widely studied. This study was motivated not only by their magnetic applications, but also due to the diversity of network topologies that can be accessed by using the most common oxidation states (2 and 3) adopted by iron atoms and different conformations around iron metal centers . On the other hand, the imidazole group is known to function as a ligand toward transition metal ions in a variety of biologically important molecules including: iron heme systems; vitamin B12 and several other metalloproteins . Consequently, a wide variety of imidazole containing ligands has been investigated with a view to mimicking the structural features present in the active site of these enzymes . Pyrazole-based ligands may be used also as synthetic analogs of imidazole and mimic the coordinating sites of metal enzymes or metalloproteins . In comparison with the monodentate N-donor ligands, flexible ligands containing N-donor heterocyclic groups can adopt different conformations and low symmetry as a consequence of rotations about C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C single bonds. These can lead to generate particular structures with interesting properties . Architectures with specific structural motifs can be achieved by careful selection of organic ligands with suitable coordinating groups, metal centers with definite coordination geometry and reaction conditions . We have previously concentrated on the coordination chemistry of pyrazole-derived ligands . In our continuation of synthesis and structural studies of transition metal complexes, it is of great research interest to study the design, synthesis and structural characterization of new iron(II) complexes with the neutral flexible pyrazole and imidazole based ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). Such study can reveal the role of the variation of the ligand and metal coordination modes, the length and flexibility of the spacer group between the heterocyclic aromatic rings and non-classical bonds on the final structure of iron(II) coordination compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and construction of iron coordination polymers have been widely studied. This study was motivated not only by their magnetic applications, but also due to the diversity of network topologies that can be accessed by using the most common oxidation states (2 and 3) adopted by iron atoms and different conformations around iron metal centers . On the other hand, the imidazole group is known to function as a ligand toward transition metal ions in a variety of biologically important molecules including: iron heme systems; vitamin B12 and several other metalloproteins . Consequently, a wide variety of imidazole containing ligands has been investigated with a view to mimicking the structural features present in the active site of these enzymes . Pyrazole-based ligands may be used also as synthetic analogs of imidazole and mimic the coordinating sites of metal enzymes or metalloproteins . In comparison with the monodentate N-donor ligands, flexible ligands containing N-donor heterocyclic groups can adopt different conformations and low symmetry as a consequence of rotations about CC single bonds. These can lead to generate particular structures with interesting properties . Architectures with specific structural motifs can be achieved by careful selection of organic ligands with suitable coordinating groups, metal centers with definite coordination geometry and reaction conditions . We have previously concentrated on the coordination chemistry of pyrazole-derived ligands . In our continuation of synthesis and structural studies of transition metal complexes, it is of great research interest to study the design, synthesis and structural characterization of new iron(II) complexes with the neutral flexible pyrazole and imidazole based ligands ( ). Such study can reveal the role of the variation of the ligand and metal coordination modes, the length and flexibility of the spacer group between the heterocyclic aromatic rings and non-classical bonds on the final structure of iron(II) coordination compounds.

<ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">Materials and general methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">All experiments were carried out in air. Starting materials were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligands bib , bpp  and bbd  were prepared from them by published methods. Infrared spectra (4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) were recorded from KBr disks with a BOMEN MB102 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were performed on a Thermo Finigan Flash EA 1120 CHN analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a Philips X’Pert Pro diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.54184<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) in the 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> range 5–50°. Thermal analysis for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was performed on a Bahr-STA 503 TG/DTA thermal analyzers under dynamic nitrogen. A ramp rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in the range of 50–1200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C was used.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and general methods

All experiments were carried out in air. Starting materials were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligands bib , bpp  and bbd  were prepared from them by published methods. Infrared spectra (4000-400cm-1) were recorded from KBr disks with a BOMEN MB102 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were performed on a Thermo Finigan Flash EA 1120 CHN analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a Philips X'Pert Pro diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ =1.54184Å) in the 2θ range 5-50°. Thermal analysis for 1 was performed on a Bahr-STA 503 TG/DTA thermal analyzers under dynamic nitrogen. A ramp rate of 10°Cmin-1 in the range of 50-1200°C was used.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Preparation of [Fe(bib)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">A mixture of EtOH and water (1:1, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was gently layered on the top of an aqueous solution (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of Fe(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.036<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in a test tube. A solution of bib (0.038<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and KNCS (0.019<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in EtOH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (2:1, 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was added carefully as a third layer. Needle colorless crystals were obtained after 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. They were washed with water and dried in air. (0.037<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 67% based on Fe). Anal. calcd. (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>FeN<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C 48.18, H 4.41, N 25.54; found: C 48.09, H 4.38, N 25.39. Preparation of [Fe(bib)2(NCS)2]n (1)

A mixture of EtOH and water (1:1, 5mL) was gently layered on the top of an aqueous solution (5mL) of Fe(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.036g, 0.10mmol) in a test tube. A solution of bib (0.038g, 0.20mmol) and KNCS (0.019g, 0.20mmol) in EtOH/H2O (2:1, 6mL) was added carefully as a third layer. Needle colorless crystals were obtained after 6days. They were washed with water and dried in air. (0.037g, 67% based on Fe). Anal. calcd. (%) for C22H24FeN10S2: C 48.18, H 4.41, N 25.54; found: C 48.09, H 4.38, N 25.39. Selected IR (KBr, cm-1): 3116 (m), 2934 (m), 2858 (w), 2066 (vs), 1514 (m), 1449 (m), 1357 (w), 1280 (w), 1230 (m), 1107 (s), 1092 (s), 1029 (w), 936 (s), 839 (s), 823 (m), 759 (m), 662 (s), 628 (m).

Preparation of [Fe(bpp)(NCS)2] (2)

A mixture of EtOH and water (1:1, 5mL) was gently layered on the top of an aqueous solution (5mL) of Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2⋅6H2O (0.39g, 1.0mmol) and KNCS (0.18g, 2.0mmol) in a test tube. A solution of bpp (0.12g, 0.50mmol) in EtOH (5mL) was added carefully as a third layer. Colorless crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained after 3weeks. They were collected and washed with small amount of water and dried in air (0.32g, 79% based on Fe). Anal. calcd. (%) for C15H20FeN6S2: C, 44.56; H, 4.99; N, 20.79. Found: C, 44.43; H, 4.96; N, 20.67. IR data (cm-1): 3122 (m), 2961 (w), 2923 (m), 2062 (vs), 1545 (s), 1461 (s), 1422 (w), 1371 (s), 1319 (w), 1294 (w), 1203 (m), 1158 (w), 1126 (m), 1042(s), 1023 (m), 971 (m), 811 (s), 758 (m), 746 (m), 617 (m).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Attempted preparation of [Fe(bbd)(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The procedure was the same as that described for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, except that bbd (0.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was used instead of bpp ligand. The reaction was carried out at room temperature and under the reflux conditions. The absence of a strong band in the infrared spectrum of reaction residue which expected around 2063<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(CN) of the N-bonded thiocyanate is an evidence that no reaction was performed among the reactants.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Attempted preparation of [Fe(bbd)(NCS)2] (3)

The procedure was the same as that described for 2, except that bbd (0.12g, 0.50mmol) was used instead of bpp ligand. The reaction was carried out at room temperature and under the reflux conditions. The absence of a strong band in the infrared spectrum of reaction residue which expected around 2063cm-1 for ν(CN) of the N-bonded thiocyanate is an evidence that no reaction was performed among the reactants.

elements.clean_text:
Hazard: Perchlorate compounds are potentially explosive and should be handled with care.

X-ray crystallography

X-ray data for compounds 1 and 2 were collected at room temperature with a Bruker APEX II CCD area-detector diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Data collection, cell refinement, data reduction and absorption correction were performed by using multi scan methods with Bruker software . The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR2004 . The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full matrix least squares method on F 2 using SHELXL . All the hydrogen (H) atoms were placed at the calculated positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. Details concerning collection and analysis are reported in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

Compounds 1 and 2 were prepared by the reactions  in an ethanol-water solution as a solvent.  (1)  Fe   (   ClO   4   )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 2 KNCS + 2 bib → [ Fe   ( bib )   2     ( NCS )   2   ] + 2   KClO   4   + 6   H   2   O      (2)  Fe   (   NH   4   )   2     (   SO   4   )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 2 KNCS + bpp → [ Fe ( bpp )   ( NCS )   2   ] +   (   NH   4   )   2     SO   4   +   K   2     SO   4   + 6   H   2   O

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">These compounds are relatively stable and can be stored in a desiccator for a month. Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is insoluble in common organic solvents such as DMF, DMSO and MeCN. Direct mixing of the reactants is not a general method for the preparation of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, as it leads to the formation of a precipitate or undesirable product. In order to get suitable crystals for the X-ray crystallography a three-layer diffusion method were used. In this method a buffer band (ethanol–water) is utilized to separate the two solutions, one of them is an aqueous solution of the iron(II) salt and the other is an ethanol solution of the bib ligand. When these two solutions diffuse into the buffer band and meet with each other, the product slowly forms and crystallizes in the buffer band. Replacing bib with the bpp ligand, change the structure of the product from polymer to a monomeric structure. This observation can be attributed to the shorter spacer length and steric hindrance of the methyl groups of bpp as compare with the bib ligand. On the other hand, in an attempt to replace bpp with the bbd ligand was failed. Because the steric hindrance of the methyl groups is an obstacle for the formation of a polymeric structure and the longer spacer length of the bbd prevent to form a stable ring in a mononuclear complex. Therefore the flexible ligands play a significant role in the formation and structures of iron(II) coordination compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: These compounds are relatively stable and can be stored in a desiccator for a month. Polymer 1 is insoluble in common organic solvents such as DMF, DMSO and MeCN. Direct mixing of the reactants is not a general method for the preparation of polymer 1, as it leads to the formation of a precipitate or undesirable product. In order to get suitable crystals for the X-ray crystallography a three-layer diffusion method were used. In this method a buffer band (ethanol-water) is utilized to separate the two solutions, one of them is an aqueous solution of the iron(II) salt and the other is an ethanol solution of the bib ligand. When these two solutions diffuse into the buffer band and meet with each other, the product slowly forms and crystallizes in the buffer band. Replacing bib with the bpp ligand, change the structure of the product from polymer to a monomeric structure. This observation can be attributed to the shorter spacer length and steric hindrance of the methyl groups of bpp as compare with the bib ligand. On the other hand, in an attempt to replace bpp with the bbd ligand was failed. Because the steric hindrance of the methyl groups is an obstacle for the formation of a polymeric structure and the longer spacer length of the bbd prevent to form a stable ring in a mononuclear complex. Therefore the flexible ligands play a significant role in the formation and structures of iron(II) coordination compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st050">Description of crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st055">Crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Single crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that this compound crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 with <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 (). As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, each Fe(II) resides on an inversion center and assumes the axially compressed octahedral coordination geometry. There are two crystallographically different iron(II) ions in the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with different Fe<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">imidazolyl</ce:inf> and Fe<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">NCS</ce:inf> bond lengths (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>). This can be attributed to the fact that, the bib ligands represent two different types of conformations (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a), namely <ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic> (red color) with shortest N···N and Fe···Fe distances of 7.010 and 8.536<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and dihedral angles of the two imidazole rings of 49.26° and <ce:italic>anti–anti–anti</ce:italic> (green color) with shortest N···N and Fe···Fe distances of 8.853 and 12.580<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and dihedral angles of the two imidazole rings of 0°. The NCS groups are almost linear at carbon [N(2)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C(21)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>S(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>179.0(3)°, N(2)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C(22)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>S(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>179.0(3)°] and slightly bent at N atom [Fe(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N(2)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C(21)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>159.0(3)°, Fe(2)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N(7)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C(22)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>158.7(3)°] as is usual for an N-bonded thiocyanate ligand. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a non-interpenetrating three-dimensional network of four-connected nodes with an uncommon (6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>8) CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-type topology (b). These layers are linked by intermolecular forces such as π–π stacking interactions with centroid distance of 3.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å which exist between the parallel neighboring imidazole rings (). The coordination geometry of iron atoms and network topology of this structure are very similar to those observed in the 3D polymer of [Fe(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (btb<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane . In contrast to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, in the structure of [Fe(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O a pair of identical CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-like nets is interlocked with each other and form a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3D architecture. Structural compression between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, [Fe(btp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [btp<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propane] and [Fe(btx)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5EtOH·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN [btx<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene] shows that the [Fe(btp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5EtOH·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN is a 1D-linear chain coordination polymer while, [Fe(btx)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] has a 2D (4,4) sheet-like structure . Accordingly, the flexible ligands are responsible for directing the dimensionality of these polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of crystal structures

Crystal structure of 1 

Single crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that this compound crystallizes in the triclinic space group P -1 with Z =2 (). As shown in  , each Fe(II) resides on an inversion center and assumes the axially compressed octahedral coordination geometry. There are two crystallographically different iron(II) ions in the asymmetric unit of 1 with different FeNimidazolyl and FeNNCS bond lengths ( ). This can be attributed to the fact that, the bib ligands represent two different types of conformations ( a), namely gauche-anti-gauche (red color) with shortest N⋅⋅⋅N and Fe⋅⋅⋅Fe distances of 7.010 and 8.536Å and dihedral angles of the two imidazole rings of 49.26° and anti-anti-anti (green color) with shortest N⋅⋅⋅N and Fe⋅⋅⋅Fe distances of 8.853 and 12.580Å and dihedral angles of the two imidazole rings of 0°. The NCS groups are almost linear at carbon [N(2)C(21)S(1)=179.0(3)°, N(2)C(22)S(2)=179.0(3)°] and slightly bent at N atom [Fe(1)N(2)C(21)=159.0(3)°, Fe(2)N(7)C(22)=158.7(3)°] as is usual for an N-bonded thiocyanate ligand. Compound 1 exhibits a non-interpenetrating three-dimensional network of four-connected nodes with an uncommon (658) CdSO4-type topology (b). These layers are linked by intermolecular forces such as π-π stacking interactions with centroid distance of 3.90Å which exist between the parallel neighboring imidazole rings (). The coordination geometry of iron atoms and network topology of this structure are very similar to those observed in the 3D polymer of [Fe(btb)2(NCS)2]⋅H2O (btb=1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane . In contrast to 1, in the structure of [Fe(btb)2(NCS)2]⋅H2O a pair of identical CdSO4-like nets is interlocked with each other and form a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D→3D architecture. Structural compression between 1, [Fe(btp)2(NCS)2] [btp=1,3-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propane] and [Fe(btx)2(NCS)2]⋅0.5EtOH⋅CH3CN [btx=1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene] shows that the [Fe(btp)2(NCS)2]⋅0.5EtOH⋅CH3CN is a 1D-linear chain coordination polymer while, [Fe(btx)2(NCS)2] has a 2D (4,4) sheet-like structure . Accordingly, the flexible ligands are responsible for directing the dimensionality of these polymers.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st060">Crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">This compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1) with <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 (). Selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in . As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor> in the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there are two independent molecules with a similar coordination environment. In each of them, the iron(II) ion has a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry with large compression of the N(6)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Fe(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N(1) angle [100.7(2)°] and enlargement of the N(5)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Fe(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N(1) angle [111.6(2)°] in one molecule, N(12)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Fe(2)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N(10) angle [103.2(2)°] and N(12)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Fe(2)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N(11) angle [113.8(3)°] in the other molecule. Here, the bpp ligand adopts its common chelating mode of a single metal center in a mononuclear complex. The ligand is coordinated to iron(II) ion in a cyclic-bidentate fashion forming a very flexible eight-membered metallocycle similar to the previously reported for bpp ligand in nickel(II) , zinc(II) and cooper(II) complexes . The coordination of the bpp ligand is rather unsymmetrical with two different Fe<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">imidazolyl</ce:inf> bond lengths of 2.053(5) and 2.062(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in one molecule, 2.044(5) and 2.039<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in the other molecule. On best of our knowledge these compounds represent the only known structurally characterized examples of this ligand with any metals. Structural comparison show that the neutral bidentate bridging bis(pyrazol-1-yl)methane ligands gives less flexible six-membered ring  and 1,2-bis(pyrazol-1-yl)ethanes forming a boat-shaped seven-membered chelate ring . Ligands with four and more methylene groups in the spacer act as bridging in coordination polymers of various structures. Thus, the spacer of the flexible ligands plays an important role in the structure of the coordination compounds . The Fe<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:inf loc="post">NCS</ce:inf> bond lengths are also different in these two molecules, 1.975(6) and 1.971(6) in one molecule, 1.967(6) and 1.952(6) in the other molecule.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 2 

This compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2(1) with Z =2 (). Selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in . As shown in   in the asymmetric unit of 2, there are two independent molecules with a similar coordination environment. In each of them, the iron(II) ion has a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry with large compression of the N(6)Fe(1)N(1) angle [100.7(2)°] and enlargement of the N(5)Fe(1)N(1) angle [111.6(2)°] in one molecule, N(12)Fe(2)N(10) angle [103.2(2)°] and N(12)Fe(2)N(11) angle [113.8(3)°] in the other molecule. Here, the bpp ligand adopts its common chelating mode of a single metal center in a mononuclear complex. The ligand is coordinated to iron(II) ion in a cyclic-bidentate fashion forming a very flexible eight-membered metallocycle similar to the previously reported for bpp ligand in nickel(II) , zinc(II) and cooper(II) complexes . The coordination of the bpp ligand is rather unsymmetrical with two different FeNimidazolyl bond lengths of 2.053(5) and 2.062(5)Å in one molecule, 2.044(5) and 2.039Å in the other molecule. On best of our knowledge these compounds represent the only known structurally characterized examples of this ligand with any metals. Structural comparison show that the neutral bidentate bridging bis(pyrazol-1-yl)methane ligands gives less flexible six-membered ring  and 1,2-bis(pyrazol-1-yl)ethanes forming a boat-shaped seven-membered chelate ring . Ligands with four and more methylene groups in the spacer act as bridging in coordination polymers of various structures. Thus, the spacer of the flexible ligands plays an important role in the structure of the coordination compounds . The FeNNCS bond lengths are also different in these two molecules, 1.975(6) and 1.971(6) in one molecule, 1.967(6) and 1.952(6) in the other molecule.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st065">Spectroscopic characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The IR spectra of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit strong bands corresponding to the stretching vibration of the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N bonds of the imidazole and 3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl rings of the bib and bpp ligands at the range of 1514 and 1545<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. The medium bands in the range of 3116–2858<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> assign to the C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H stretching vibrations of the methylene group [<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>] of the aliphatic spacer unit. Intense absorption bands at 2066<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 2062<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are attributed to the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(CN) of the terminal N-coordinated thiocyanate ligand. This is consistent with the crystal structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The purity of the synthesized compounds was checked by performing X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) in which the experimental spectra were consistent with their simulated spectrum ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic characterization

The IR spectra of compounds 1 and 2 exhibit strong bands corresponding to the stretching vibration of the CN bonds of the imidazole and 3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl rings of the bib and bpp ligands at the range of 1514 and 1545cm-1, respectively. The medium bands in the range of 3116-2858cm-1 assign to the CH stretching vibrations of the methylene group [(CH2)] of the aliphatic spacer unit. Intense absorption bands at 2066cm-1 for 1 and 2062cm-1 for 2 are attributed to the ν(CN) of the terminal N-coordinated thiocyanate ligand. This is consistent with the crystal structures of 1 and 2. The purity of the synthesized compounds was checked by performing X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) in which the experimental spectra were consistent with their simulated spectrum ().

<ce:section-title id="st070">Thermal analysis properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In order to examine the thermal stability of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for this compound at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in the temperature range of 50–1200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under the nitrogen atmosphere. Thermal gravimetric analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows that this compound is stable up to ca. 270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The thermogram for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>) exhibits two main steps of weight losses. The first step started at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and completed at 410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C during which the bib ligands are partially burned. The second step covers from 410 to 660<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds to the further decomposition of the polymer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis properties

In order to examine the thermal stability of polymer 1, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for this compound at a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 in the temperature range of 50-1200°C under the nitrogen atmosphere. Thermal gravimetric analysis of 1 shows that this compound is stable up to ca. 270°C. The thermogram for 1 ( ) exhibits two main steps of weight losses. The first step started at 300°C and completed at 410°C during which the bib ligands are partially burned. The second step covers from 410 to 660°C corresponds to the further decomposition of the polymer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st075">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In summary, by using the flexible ligands bib and bpp and appropriate iron(II) salt with the KNCS, we successfully obtained two novel iron(II) coordination compounds with different structures. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, has a polymeric structure with CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> network while, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a mononuclear complex with an eight-membered metallocyclic ring. These observations clearly attributed to the effects of the flexible ligands on the final structure of the complexes. An attempt to synthesize [Fe(bbd)(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (bbd<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl)butane) with the reaction of bbd, Fe(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and KNCS was failed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, by using the flexible ligands bib and bpp and appropriate iron(II) salt with the KNCS, we successfully obtained two novel iron(II) coordination compounds with different structures. Complex 1, has a polymeric structure with CdSO4 network while, compound 2 is a mononuclear complex with an eight-membered metallocyclic ring. These observations clearly attributed to the effects of the flexible ligands on the final structure of the complexes. An attempt to synthesize [Fe(bbd)(NCS)2] (bbd=1,4-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazolyl)butane) with the reaction of bbd, Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2⋅6H2O and KNCS was failed.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Fe(bib)2(NCS)2]n (1)

A mixture of EtOH and water (1:1, 5mL) was gently layered on the top of an aqueous solution (5mL) of Fe(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.036g, 0.10mmol) in a test tube. A solution of bib (0.038g, 0.20mmol) and KNCS (0.019g, 0.20mmol) in EtOH/H2O (2:1, 6mL) was added carefully as a third layer. Needle colorless crystals were obtained after 6days. They were washed with water and dried in air. (0.037g, 67% based on Fe). Anal. calcd. (%) for C22H24FeN10S2: C 48.18, H 4.41, N 25.54; found: C 48.09, H 4.38, N 25.39. Selected IR (KBr, cm-1): 3116 (m), 2934 (m), 2858 (w), 2066 (vs), 1514 (m), 1449 (m), 1357 (w), 1280 (w), 1230 (m), 1107 (s), 1092 (s), 1029 (w), 936 (s), 839 (s), 823 (m), 759 (m), 662 (s), 628 (m).

Preparation of [Fe(bpp)(NCS)2] (2)

A mixture of EtOH and water (1:1, 5mL) was gently layered on the top of an aqueous solution (5mL) of Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2⋅6H2O (0.39g, 1.0mmol) and KNCS (0.18g, 2.0mmol) in a test tube. A solution of bpp (0.12g, 0.50mmol) in EtOH (5mL) was added carefully as a third layer. Colorless crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained after 3weeks. They were collected and washed with small amount of water and dried in air (0.32g, 79% based on Fe). Anal. calcd. (%) for C15H20FeN6S2: C, 44.56; H, 4.99; N, 20.79. Found: C, 44.43; H, 4.96; N, 20.67. IR data (cm-1): 3122 (m), 2961 (w), 2923 (m), 2062 (vs), 1545 (s), 1461 (s), 1422 (w), 1371 (s), 1319 (w), 1294 (w), 1203 (m), 1158 (w), 1126 (m), 1042(s), 1023 (m), 971 (m), 811 (s), 758 (m), 746 (m), 617 (m).

Attempted preparation of [Fe(bbd)(NCS)2] (3)

The procedure was the same as that described for 2, except that bbd (0.12g, 0.50mmol) was used instead of bpp ligand. The reaction was carried out at room temperature and under the reflux conditions. The absence of a strong band in the infrared spectrum of reaction residue which expected around 2063cm-1 for ν(CN) of the N-bonded thiocyanate is an evidence that no reaction was performed among the reactants.

Thermal analysis properties

In order to examine the thermal stability of polymer 1, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for this compound at a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 in the temperature range of 50-1200°C under the nitrogen atmosphere. Thermal gravimetric analysis of 1 shows that this compound is stable up to ca. 270°C. The thermogram for 1 ( ) exhibits two main steps of weight losses. The first step started at 300°C and completed at 410°C during which the bib ligands are partially burned. The second step covers from 410 to 660°C corresponds to the further decomposition of the polymer.
